comments.html:
great! works well here.

watch out if you're running 12.4(15)T on an 877 with the v5 IPS stuff configured - you'll get told "Not enough free memory to launch Tcl shell" (even with 256MB!), which is a shame.
comments.name: cos

comments.html: cos: it's not a shame, it's a feature. Try scripting tcl low-memory low water memory mark.
comments.name: xabrouck

comments.html: aha! thank you very much for that. I haven't yet been able to find any info on it on cisco's website, though - is there a default value, for instance?
comments.name: cos

comments.html: cos: it's apparently 1/4 of the free processor memory when TCL gets initialized.  Open a TAC SR if this is a concern.
comments.name: xabrouck

comments.html:
Ivan,

Just tried out this script and I've noticed that it insists on writing to the first tty no matter where it's executed from.

Example - I put the script in and setup the alias and it works fine. I had a colleague login and when he executed the command, the output displayed on my tty. Once I logged out, he had to logout and log back in for it to work on his terminal.

Also, is there a way to paginate the output?

Thanks for the great tip!
Roddie
comments.name: Anonymous

comments.html: Minor correction - It seems to be writing to the first line not TTY.
comments.name: Anonymous
